relation: Optional. Specify the target GUID value of a configured target. Note: When you configure a target, Oracle Privileged Account Manager automatically assigns a unique target GUID. Refer to Section 6.2, "Adding Targets to Oracle Privileged Account Manager" for more information.
Optional. Specify the target name of a configured target.
Optional. Specify a default value for the account password. Note: This field becomes a required field if the target type is lockbox.
Optional. Provide a description of the account.
Provide a name for the new account.
Optional. Enables or disables the requirement for connection validation. true: Skips connection validation. false (default): Enforces connection validation.
Optional. Displays usage options for this command.
pageTitle: Working with the Command Line Tool
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {32183=Optional. Specify an hour. For example, specify 5 if the expiration time should be 5:00., 32330=Optional. Specify the minutes. For example, specify 30 if the expiration time should be 5:30.}
textBeforeTable: The following table describes the options you can use with this command: [-url <url>] -u <username> [-p <password>] [-debug] -x addaccount <options>  Command Syntax: You must never use the same account as the service account and as a privileged account to be managed by Oracle Privileged Account Manager. Refer to Chapter 7, "Working with Service Accounts" for information about service accounts. Note: Use the addaccount command to add a privileged account. A.5.1 addaccount Command Section A.5.13, "showpasswordhistory Command" Section A.5.12, "showpassword Command" Section A.5.11, "searchcheckouthistory Command" Section A.5.10, "searchaccount Command" Section A.5.9, "retrieveaccount Command" Section A.5.8, "resetpassword Command" Section A.5.7, "removeaccount Command" Section A.5.6, "modifyaccount Command" Section A.5.5, "displaycheckedoutaccounts Command" Section A.5.4, "checkout Command" Section A.5.3, "checkin Command" Section A.5.2, "displayallaccounts Command" Section A.5.1, "addaccount Command" The following sections contain information about the commands that you use when working with Oracle Privileged Account Manager privileged accounts. A.5 Working with Accounts You use either <targetid> or <targetname> to identify
textAfterTable: Note: You use either <targetid> or <targetname> to identify the target. Both values are unique. You can use -password to set up an account password. A.5.2 displayallaccounts Command Use the displayallaccounts command to display a listing of all accounts. Note: You must be an administrator with the User Manager Admin Role or the Security Administrator Admin Role to successfully run this command. Command Syntax:  [-url <url>] -u <username> [-p <password>] [-debug] -x displayallaccounts <options> The following table describes the options you can use with this command: Option Description [-help] Optional. Displays usage options for this command. A.5.3 checkin Command Use the checkin command to check in privileged accounts.
